facts.text: Mehtab Singh was the owner of Akbar Building in Mohalla Ganda Nala, Gali Rajan, Delhi. Appellant was a tenant under him in respect of certain accommodation.
On June 3, 1955, Mehtab Singh filed a suit under the Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952 against the appellant for ejectment.
On October 11, 1956, the suit was decreed for ejectment.
Appellant's appeal against the decree was dismissed on March 27, 1957.
Appellant's revision petition to Punjab High Court dismissed sometime between March and September 1957.
Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956 came into force on February 8, 1957.
Notification under s.3 of Slum Areas Act declaring the area a slum area issued before September 1957.
Mehtab Singh applied for permission under s.19 Slum Areas Act to execute ejectment decree; refused on September 12, 1957.
Appeal against refusal rejected on January 7, 1958.
Mehtab Singh sold the building to the respondent on August 21, 1961.
On or about March 28, 1962, respondent filed suit in Court of Sub-Judge, Delhi against appellant for possession, claiming appellant trespasser due to 1956 ejectment decree.
Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 came into force on February 19, 1959, repealing Ajmer Act for Delhi.
Trial court (Sub-Judge) held respondent owner; on issues 2-3 held appellant still tenant as decree inexecutable under s.19 Slum Act; dismissed suit for want of jurisdiction under s.50 Delhi Rent Act.
Respondent appealed to Punjab High Court (Regular First Appeal No. 209-D of 1962); High Court on May 12, 1964 set aside trial court judgment, held appellant not tenant, remanded for merits.
Special leave to appeal to Supreme Court granted on August 14, 1964.
After remand, Sub-Judge decreed for respondent on August 12, 1964; appeal pending in High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether notwithstanding s.19 of Slum Areas Act rendering ejectment decree inexecutable, the appellant ceased to be a tenant within the meaning of s.2(l) Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958, thereby giving civil court jurisdiction under ordinary law.
Whether civil court barred by s.50 Delhi Rent Control Act from entertaining suit for eviction against person who suffered ejectment decree.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.19 Slum Areas Act bars the suit; civil court has no jurisdiction under s.50 Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 as appellant continues to be tenant despite decree, since decree inexecutable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Slum Areas Act s.19; Delhi Rent Control Act 1958 s.2(l), s.50

petitioner_arguments.text: S.25 and s.50 Delhi Rent Act bar civil court as Controller empowered to execute eviction orders.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Rent Control Act 1958 s.25, s.50, s.42

petitioner_arguments.text: Once ejectment order made, no fresh order possible regardless of executability.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant in unauthorised occupation, trespasser post 1956 ejectment decree obtained by previous owner.

court_reasoning.text: S.2(l) Delhi Rent Control Act 1958 excludes from 'tenant' any person against whom decree/order for eviction made; decree existence matters, not executability under Slum Act s.19.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tenant who suffered ejectment decree no longer tenant under Act of 1958.

court_reasoning.text: S.50 bars civil court only for eviction of 'tenant' as defined; does not bar suit against non-tenant trespasser.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Civil court can decide if person trespasser post eviction decree.

court_reasoning.text: S.19 Slum Act assumes tenant prior to decree but does not define tenant or restore tenancy; Act of 1958 definition unaffected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Slum Act not concerned with landlord-tenant relations definitionally.

court_reasoning.text: S.42 empowers Controller to execute orders; civil court not executing but deciding status.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No bar on civil court determining if ceased to be tenant.

court_reasoning.text: Jyoti Pershad inapplicable as dealt with constitutionality, not definition of tenant post-decree.

holdings.text: Person against whom eviction decree passed ceases to be tenant under s.2(l) Delhi Rent Control Act 1958, regardless of s.19 Slum Areas Act inexecutability.
Civil court has jurisdiction to entertain suit for possession against such person as trespasser; s.50 does not bar.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. The Administration for the Union Territory of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with constitutionality of Slum Areas Act and protections to tenants, not whether eviction decree holder remains tenant under Rent Act definition.

statutes_cited.name: Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires permission for execution of eviction decrees in slum areas; does not affect tenant definition or restore tenancy.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines tenant excluding those with eviction decree/order; bars civil court jurisdiction for tenant eviction but not for non-tenants.

statutes_cited.name: Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Under which original ejectment suit/decree obtained.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's view that trial court had jurisdiction as appellant not tenant under Delhi Rent Act 1958 post ejectment decree; confined to jurisdiction issue, noted post-remand decree but left merits appeal to High Court.

key_quotes.text: "a tenant who had suffered a decree in ejectment was no more a tenant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on s.2(l) Delhi Rent Act definition.

key_quotes.text: "It does not follow that because a civil court cannot execute a decree for eviction passed by a Controller, it cannot also decide the question whether a tenant against whom such an order has been passed has ceased to be a tenant and become a trespasser."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Section 19 only says that a person who has obtained a decree in ejectment against a tenant shall not be entitled to execute it without the previous permission of the prescribed authority. It does not say that a tenant suffering the decree still continues to be a tenant for any purpose."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes Slum Act effect on tenancy status.
